titlestmt.title: There is No Natural Religion Copy C : electronic edition
titlestmt.principal: Editors: Morris Eaves, University of Rochester; Robert Essick, University of California, Riverside; and Joseph Viscomi, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
titlestmt.respstmt: Programmer/Analysts: David Cosca and Robert BinglerProject Manager: Matthew KirschenbaumProject Assistant: Greg Murray
titlestmt.sponsor: The Institute for Advanced Technology in the Humanities, the Library of Congress, and the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with a software grant from Inso Corporation and hardware and software grants from Sun Microsystems
titlestmt.funder: Paul Mellon Centre for Studies in British Art, 1997-98

filedesc.extent: XML file derived from 1 SGML (ISO 8879) encoded file approx. 70KB; 24 JPEG (ISO/IEC 10918) files ranging in size from 13KB to 120KB
filedesc.publicationstmt: Charlottesville: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; IATH June 1998
filedesc.updatestmt:
The editors of the William Blake Archive are pleased to announce the publication of six new electronic editions of Blake's illuminated books. They are: All Religions are One Copy A, There is No Natural Religion Copies B, C, G, and L, and Milton, a Poem Copy C.
Composed and executed in 1788, All Religions are One and There is No Natural Religion are Blake's first works in illuminated printing, though no copy of either work survives from this date. The ten plates of All Religions were followed quickly by twenty No Natural Religion plates in two antithetical sets (a and b series). Only one copy of All Religion is extant, now in the Huntington Library, printed c. 1795 with and in the same style as There is No Natural Religion Copy L, the only copy consisting exclusively of the ten b-series of plates, now in The Pierpont Morgan Library. The other twelve recorded copies of this book consist of a mixture of the same eight to twelve plates, which appeared to be merely incomplete sets of proofs until it was discovered that six of these copies were 19th-century reproductions. Once the inauthentic impressions were weeded out, it became apparent that what remained was Blake's selection of a and b plates for an abridged version of the work printed around 1794. We present Copies B, C, and G of this twelve-plate work, now in the collections of the Yale Center for British Art, Library of Congress, and The Pierpont Morgan Library, respectively.
There are only four copies of Milton, Blake's most personal epic. Copy C, from the New York Public Library, was Blake's own copy. Printed c. 1811, it was later reconfigured and renumbered by Blake when he inserted extra plates, which he appears to have done on at least two different occasions.
All of these editions have newly edited texts and are all fully searchable for both text and images and supported by the unique Inote and ImageSizer applications described in our previous updates.
We now have twenty-two copies of thirteen illuminated books. Over this and next year, we will be adding Blake's last illuminated works, On Homers Poetry [&] On Virgil, The Ghost of Abel, and Laocoön, as well as Milton Copy D and Jerusalem Copy E. We will also be adding at least six more copies of Songs of Innocence and of Experience, two copies of Songs of Innocence, five copies of The Marriage of Heaven and Hell, four copies of The Book of Urizen, and two copies each of America, a Prophecy and Europe, a Prophecy. In addition, work continues on the SGML edition of David V. Erdman's Complete Poetry and Prose of William Blake.
We will continue to post updates on various lists every few months, but readers interested in the progress of the Archive can subscribe to our Blake Update list, which can be found on the Archive's Contents Page. On this page readers will also find that we have opened the top level of the Contributing Institutions Page, which provides contact information and links to institutions participating in the Archive. In the coming months, we plan to include color-coded and linked lists of each institution's entire Blake collection to indicate what is and is not in the Archive and what is forthcoming.

objdescid.origination: William Blake author, inventor, delineator, etcher, printer, colorist"The Author & Printer W Blake" is etched in reverse at the bottom of Object 1. In this copy, the lettering is partly obscured by coloring.

imprint.publisher: William BlakeBlake is named as the printer on the frontispiece, but he is also the "publisher."
imprint.pubplace: LondonThe place of publication is not given in the work, but Blake was living in London at the time of its composition and etching. He was living in the London suburb of Lambeth at the time of its printing.

objinfo.printdate: c. 1794 Reproduced here are Copy C, which lacks Bentley Plate a7, and Bentley Plate a7 (Object 7) from Copy F. All plates are from the same printing.
objinfo.objorder: Bentley Plates a1-a9, b3, b4, b12 The plates in Copy C (lacking Bentley Plate a7) are bound in an unauthorized order (Bentley Plates a2, a1, a3-a5, b4, b12, b3, a6, a8, a9). Bentley Plate a7 from Copy F has been added here as Object 7 to make a complete copy as printed c. 1794. The Plate Order recorded for Copy C as above accords with the headings, including their etched numbers, on the plates themselves.
objinfo.objsize: ranging between 4.7 x 3.7 cm. and 6.1 x 4.6 cm.
objinfo.leafsize: Objects 1, 3-6, 8, 9-12 (Copy C) are 13.4 x 10.6 cm.; Object 2 (Copy C) is 9.5 x 7.7 cm., inlaid into another sheet of paper to match the size of the other plates. Object (Copy F) is 13.9 x 11.4 cm.
objinfo.medium: relief etching with touches of white-line etching on some plates
objinfo.printingstyle: relief, with rudimentary color printing on most plates
objinfo.inkcolor: Objects 1, 3, 4, 7-12, burnt umber or olive brown; Object 2, black; Objects 5 and 6, green
objinfo.support: wove paper There are no watermarks in Copy C, but the paper is probably the same as the paper in Copy B, one plate in which shows a "TAYLOR" watermark. Except for Object 7 (Bentley Plate a7), Copy F consists of nineteenth-century reproductions.
objinfo.etchednumbers: NoneThe etched numbers I-IV on Objects 4-9 and I-II on Objects 10 and 11, are headings, not plate numbers.
objinfo.binding: Copy C is in green levant morocco by Francis Bedford. Copy F (from which Object 7 is reproduced here) is loose.
objinfo.stabholes: in the margin of Object 2 only

provenance.name: both Copies C and F, Library of Congress
provenance.date: Copy C acquired by Lessing J. Rosenwald in May 1929; given to the Library of Congress in 1945. Copy F acquired by Lessing J. Rosenwald in April 1941; given to the Library of Congress in 1945.
provenance.dealer: both Copies C and F, A. S. W. Rosenbach
provenance.price: Copy C unknown; Copy F $1500 plus dealer's fees
provenance.note: Copy C, Basil Montagu Pickering by the 1860s; Frederick Locker no later than 1876 (Bentley Plates a2, a5, and a6 added by Locker); Dodd, Mead and Co.; William A. White in April 1905; sold from White's estate, May 1929, through the dealer A. S. W. Rosenbach to Lessing J. Rosenwald; given by Rosenwald to the Library of Congress in 1945. Copy F, consisting of eight reproductions, was part of a large group of such reproductions acquired by Stopford Brooke and R. A. Potts in the nineteenth century; sold Sotheby's, 20 Feb. 1913, lot 65, "11" leaves (the dealer James Tregaskis, £13); Bentley Plate 7a (reproduced here as Object 7), inscribed in an unknown hand "given me by Mr Tatham" and the only original impression in the copy, added at an unknown time prior to the sale of this copy, American Art Association auction, New York, 21 May 1923, lot 10A, "8 plates" (price and purchaser not recorded); sold from the collection of Henry D. Hughes, American Art Association, 22 April 1924, lot 59, "8 plates" (probably to a dealer acting for A. E. Newton, $600); sold from the estate of A. E. Newton, Parke-Bernet, 16 April 1941, lot 153, "9 plates" (to the dealer A. S. W. Rosenbach acting for Lessing J. Rosenwald, $1500); given by Rosenwald to the Library of Congress, 1945.

desc.objtitle: , Object 1 (Bentley a1, Erdman a1, Keynes a2)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two youthful males, both nude and with curly hair, stand on the right. The youth furthest to the right appears to have his left arm raised and may have his left hand resting on the tree trunk near the right margin. The youth furthest to the left holds a shepherd's crook in his right hand, although this prints as only a barely-visible line. On the left is a seated couple; both the old man, with a long beard, and the woman wear gowns. The man appears to be seated on a fluted pillar. The woman may be wearing drapery (a scarf?) over her head. Another tree stands along the left margin; its branches and leaves form a canopy over the seated figures. Mountains dominate the distant landscape.

component.illusobjdesc: A youthful male, nude and with curly hair, stands on the right. He appears to have his left arm raised, perhaps with his left hand resting on the tree trunk near the right margin. His right arm is at his side. His body suggests a contrapposto posture. He looks down and to the left.

A youthful male, nude and with curly hair, stands to the left of another such figure. He holds a shepherd's crook in his right hand, although this prints only as a barely-visible line (drawn clearly in pen and ink in Copies D, G, M). Both arms are at his side. His face is partly turned to the right; he may be looking at his companion.
An old, bearded man with long hair sits on a fluted pillar. He wears a long gown and looks to the right. His right arm dangles at his side.
A woman sits behind and to the right of the old bearded man. She wears a gown and has drapery (a scarf?) over her head. Her left arm rests at her side. Her face is partly turned to the right.
A tree stands on the right. Its branches and perhaps some leaves spread out near the top of the plate.
A tree stands on the left. Its branches and leaves form a canopy at the top of the plate.
The old, bearded man on the left sits on what appears to be a fluted pillar.
The landscape background is dominated by two ranges of hills or mountains.

lg.l: The Author & Printer W BlakeIn reverse lettering, obscured by hand coloring.

desc.objtitle: THERE IS NO NATURAL RELIGION, Object 2 (Bentley a2, Erdman a2, Keynes a1)

physdesc.papersize: 9.5 x 7.7 cm., inlaid into another sheet 13.4 x 10.6 cm.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The Gothic structure of spires and arches filling most of the plate may be a church facade, a church portal, a church window, or an imaginative variation on a tomb canopy of the sort Blake saw (and probably drew) in Westminster Abbey during his apprentice years. The tracery includes at least seven human figures; the largest, upper center, may be the Virgin Mary holding the Christ child. She is flanked on each side by two praying figures. On each side of the design, between sets of spires, are a pair of standing figures, one arranged above the other. Perhaps we are to think of all these figures as statues in stone. The words of the title are incorporated into the design.

component.illusobjdesc: The Gothic structure of spires and arches filling most of the plate may be a church facade, a church portal, the tracery of a church window, or an imaginative variation on a tomb canopy of the sort Blake saw (and probably drew) in Westminster Abbey during his apprentice years. Perhaps were are to think of this architectural confection as being built of stone.

The largest figure in the design stands above the title word "There." The figure appears to be gowned and may be holding a small child or baby in (her?) left arm. If so, this figure group suggests the Virgin Mary and the Christ child. Given the context, this may be a statute in stone.
The figure standing above title word "There" may be holding a baby or small child. If so, then this may be the Virgin Mary and the Christ child. Given the context, this may be a statue in stone.

A gowned figure, apparently with hands together in prayer and looking up and to the right, stands above the first two letters of the title word "There." Given the context, this may be a statue in stone.
A gowned figure, apparently with hands together in prayer and looking to the left, stands or kneels above the final letter of the title word "There." Given the context, this may be a statue in stone.

A small gowned figure stands rigidly among the Gothic tracery left of "There" in the title inscription. Given the setting, this may be a saint; the architectural context suggests that this is a statue in stone.

A small gowned figure stands rigidly among the Gothic tracery left of "Religion" in the title inscription. The figure's right arm may be raised, bent at the elbow before his/her chest. Given the setting, this may be a saint; the architectural context suggests that this is a statue in stone.

A small gowned figure stands rigidly among the Gothic tracery right of "No" in the title inscription. Given the setting, this may be a saint; the architectural context suggests that this is a statue in stone.

A small gowned figure stands rigidly among the Gothic tracery right of "Religion" in the title inscription. His/her arms appear to be at his/her side. Given the setting, this may be a saint; the architectural context suggests that this is a statue in stone.
The title words are incorporated within the design. Perhaps we are to think of the words as inscribed in stone or on a door.

desc.objtitle: , Object 3 (Bentley a3, Erdman a3, Keynes a3)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The center of the design is dominated by a seated figure, probably female, wearing a long gown. Her legs are crossed and she holds a book or tablet on her right knee and may be writing or drawing on it with her left hand. On the right is a much smaller standing figure, probably a young girl. She is gowned and may be holding a book or piece of paper from which she reads. On the left is a figure—perhaps a young boy—lying on the ground but with his torso propped up on his left elbow. He looks down and may be reading or writing in a book. There are two trees near the right margin and one (perhaps with a vine around its trunk) near the left margin. The design would seem to relate to the theme of "Education" (E2) in the text.

component.illusobjdesc: A seated and gowned figure, probably female, holds a book or tablet on her prominent right knee and may be writing or drawing on it with her left hand. Her legs are crossed and her upper body is slightly twisted to the right.
A gowned figure, perhaps a young girl, stands right of the larger, seated figure. She looks down and to the left and perhaps reads in a book or a piece of paper she holds in her hands.

A figure, perhaps a young boy, lies on the ground left of the larger seated figure. His torso is propped up on his left elbow. He looks down and may be reading or writing (with his left hand) in a book.
Two trees, with indications of branches and leaves, grow near the right margin.
A tree, with indications of branches and leaves, grows near the left margin. There may be avine spiraling around this tree.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Several representational images hover around or on the letters of the heading ("The Argument"). These are, from left to right, a standing figure facing right and leaning against the vertical of the "T"; a figure, probably winged and thus perhaps an angel, hovering above the space between the two words; a figure standing but leaning against the left diagonal of the "A" and with one arm reaching toward the hovering figure (who may be reaching down to him); a figure right of the right diagonal of the "A," probably reaching up and to the right toward a bird hovering above the "u" and "m." It is unclear whether we are viewing the figures on the "A" from the front or the back. The first and last letters of the heading terminate in vine-like decorations.

component.illusobjdesc: A figure stands within the "T" of "The" in the heading. He or she faces to the right and leans, with at least one arm raised, against the vertical of the letter.
A figure, winged and thus perhaps an angel, hovers between the two words of the heading. He or she may be looking and reaching down toward the figure just below and to the right.

A figure stands just right of the second diagonal of the "A" in "Argument." It is unclear whether we are seeing the figure from the front or the back. His or her arm on the right reaches up and to the right toward the bird. The figure's arm on the left may also be raised to hold onto the letter.

A bird with extended wings flies above the "u" and "m" of "Argument." The direction of its flight is unclear, but the long extensions both right and left suggest a long neck (hence, a swan, crane, or stork?) and a long tail.
The ends of the "T" on the far left terminate in vine-like decorations.
The ends of the "t" terminate in vine-like decorations.

lg.l: Man has no notion of moral
Naturally he is only a natu-

desc.objtitle: , Object 4 (Bentley a4, Erdman a4, Keynes a4)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude old man leans heavily on a large staff or walking stick and looks down at a dog lying on the ground. The man's long beard cascades next to the staff. He may be bald, but perhaps with a forelock. The background landscape includes a small hill, a clump of trees on the left, and coloring in the sky on the right that may indicate clouds. A tree grows near the right margin in the foreground. One branch forms a canopy over the old man; another branch climbs along the right margin. A vine spirals around the trunk of the tree and the branch near the upper right margin. This vine continues horizontally along the top of the plate. At the vine's end, top left, sits a small human figure, perhaps playing a pipe. The very small form to the left of the figure may be a bird; there is also a bird, or a bird-like sprig of vegetation, just left of the heading number ("I").

component.illusobjdesc: A nude old man leans heavily on a staff or walking stick. He faces left and looks down at a dog lying on the ground. The man's long beard cascades next to the staff. He may be bald, but perhaps with a forelock. His left arm is bent at the elbow, the forearm extended upward along the staff.
A very small figure sits on a vine. He or she is probably facing to the left and may be playing a pipe.
A dog lies on the ground, front legs spread apart. He faces right and looks up to the old man on the right.
The very small form left of the seated figure may be a flying bird with wings spread.
A form just left of the heading number ("I") might be a bird rather than part of the vegetation. If so, the bird would seem to be flying with wings extended.
A tree grows near the right margin. One of its branches, bearing leaves, arches above the old man and dog. Another branch curves upward along the right margin.
A vine spirals around the trunk of the tree and its branch near the right margin. The vine continues horizontally along the top margin of the plate, where it may bear a few leaves.
A clump of trees fills the landscape background on the left.
A low hill fills the landscape to the right and left of the old man. Given the distance and perspective, this hill rises between his knees and hips.
The background coloring may represent clouds.

desc.objtitle: , Object 5 (Bentley a5, Erdman a5, Keynes a5)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A woman, with long or medium-length hair and wearing a long gown, kneels on the ground. She looks down and to the right at a young child she holds around with waist with her extended right arm and hand (left arm not pictured). The child, also kneeling and facing right, is probably male; there are no clear indications of clothing. He extends his arms horizontally toward a small bird near the right margin. These motifs may relate to the theme of "desires" (E2) first raised textually on plate a8. The background, right of the woman and above the child, is filled with a clump of trees. A large, leafless tree grows up the left margin and spreads a branch between the heading number ("II") and the first line of text.

component.illusobjdesc: A woman, with long or medium-length hair and wearing a long gown, kneels on the ground. She looks down and to the right at a young child she holds around the waist with her extended right arm and hand (left arm not pictured).

A young child, probably male and with no clear indications of clothing, kneels on the ground and faces to the right. His hair may be curly. While being held by a woman on the left, the child reaches, arms extended horizontally, toward a small bird near the right margin.
A bird flies from the grasp of a child.
The landscape background is filled with trees.
A leafless tree grows up the left margin. One if its branches extends between the heading number ("II") and the first line of text.

desc.objtitle: , Object 6 (Bentley a6, Erdman a6, Keynes a6)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A man, with curly hair and beard, sits on the ground. He is facing to the left and reaching with both arms in the same direction. His legs are extended horizontally to the left and he may be holding his knees. A winged putto, visible from the waist up, appears behind the seated man's legs. This second figure looks to the right and reaches toward, and perhaps touches, the seated man's right shoulder with his left hand. The putto's right arm is raised, with one finger of his right hand pointing heavenward. This gesture, and simply the winged child himself, may indicate the spiritual perceptions not available to the "3 senses" (E2). Neither figure shows any clear indications of clothing. A slender tree or vine, intertwined with a second vine, grows up the right margin and extends in loops horizontally above and below the heading number ("III") and terminates in three spirals.

component.illusobjdesc: A man, with curly hair and beard, sits on the ground. He is facing to the left, with legs extended in the same direction, and reaching with both arms to the left. He may be holding his knees. There are no clear indications of any clothing.

A winged putto, seen from the waist up, appears behind the legs of the seated man. The putto's left arm is extended horizontally; his left hand reaches toward, and may touch, the right shoulder of the seated man. The putto's right arm is raised and a finger on his right hand points heavenward. There are no clear indications of clothing.
A slender tree or vine, intertwined with a second vine, grows up the right margin and extends in loops horizontally above and below the heading number ("III") and terminates in three spirals.
A vine is intertwined around the tree or vine growing up the right margin. This second vine seems to end in the top right corner; the larger tree or vine extends horizontally to the left margin.

lg.l: -ments none could de-In Copy C, "-ments" printed poorly.

desc.objtitle: , Object 7 from Copy F (Bentley a7, Erdman a7, Keynes a7)

objnote.p: Plate a7 from Copy F has been added to make a complete copy as printed c. 1794.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A man, perhaps wearing tights or some other body-hugging costume, sits on the ground with his back against a tree. He is playing a pipe, held near his mouth with his right hand and lower on the pipe with his left. He faces to the right, with his legs extended to the right and crossed at the knee. He wears a hat, decorated with what appear to be feathers. The landscape on the right is composed of a low hill and a grove of trees. A single tree extends up the left margin. Three birds fly in the sky above the text and on each side of the heading number ("IV").

component.illusobjdesc: A man, perhaps wearing tights or some other body-hugging costume, sits on the ground with his back against a tree. He is playing a pipe, held near his mouth with his right hand and lower on the pipe with his left. He faces to the right, with his legs extended to the right and crossed at the knee. He wears a hat, decorated with what appear to be two or three feathers.
The landscape above the seated figure includes a grove of trees.
A tree grows up the left margin. One short branch arches to the right near the top of the plate.
Three birds fly above the text, one left of the heading number ("IV") and two right of the number.

desc.objtitle: , Object 8 (Bentley a8, Erdman a8, Keynes a8)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A boy with curly hair strides, right foot forward, back and to the left. He wears knee-length breeches and perhaps a shirt. With arms extended horizontally to the left and fingers spread open on at least his left hand, he reaches toward a duck or swan floating on a small body of water (perhaps a river or lake). The boy's gestures suggest the theme of "Mans desires" (E2) in the text. A tree, with an intertwined vine, grows up the left margin. One of the tree's branches, bearing a few spiky leaves, arches over the heading number and text at the top of the plate. A dark shadow extends along the ground from the base of the tree on the left to the boy's feet on the right.

component.illusobjdesc: A boy with curly hair strides, right foot forward, back and to the left. He wears knee-length breeches and perhaps a shirt. With arms extended horizontally to the left and fingers spread open on at least his left hand, he reaches toward a duck or swan on the left.
A duck or swan floats on a small body of water, perhaps a lake or river. The bird faces to the right.
A tree grows up the left margin of the plate. One of its branches, bearing a few spiky leaves, arches over the heading number and text at the top of the plate.
A vine is entwined around the lower half of the tree near the left margin.
The bird lower left appears to be floating on a small body of water, perhaps a lake or river.
A dark shadow extends along the ground from the base of the tree on the left to the boy's feet on the right.

desc.objtitle: , Object 9 (Bentley a9, Erdman a9, Keynes a9)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A figure, probably male, lies on the ground with his legs extended to the left and perhaps crossed. He props up his upper body with his arms. He holds his head in his left hand in a posture traditionally associated with melancholy. There are no clear indications of clothing. He looks down at what may be a book held by his right forearm and hand. The long, spiky leaves of two plants, or exceptionally long grasses, arch over his head from both the right and left sides of the plate. A tree grows up the right margin; its branches and leaves extend horizontally along the top of the plate. A vine is entwined around the tree's trunk. One tendril of the vine terminates in a lily-like flower just above and slightly to the right of the figure's head.

component.illusobjdesc: A figure, probably male, lies on the ground with his legs extended to the left and perhaps crossed. He props up his upper body with his arms. He holds his head in his left hand in a posture traditionally associated with melancholy. There are no clear indications of clothing. He looks down at what may be a book held by his right forearm and hand.
The long leaves of two plants, or very long grasses, arch over the figure.
A tree grows up the right margin. Its branches and leaves extend horizontally along the top margin of the plate.
A vine is intertwined around the tree near the right margin of the plate. One of the vine's tendrils terminates in a lily-like flower just above and slightly to the right of the figure's head.

desc.objtitle: , Object 10 (Bentley b3, Erdman b3, Keynes b3)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A gowned man, with curly hair and a long beard, lies on the ground. He props up his upper body on his elbows and apparently reads, or writes with his left hand, in a book on the ground before him. On the left is a clump of vegetation or perhaps the stump of a tree.

component.illusobjdesc: A gowned man, with curly hair and a long beard, lies on the ground. He props up his upper body on his elbows and apparently reads, or writes with his left hand, in a book on the ground before him.
There is a clump of vegetation, or perhaps the stump of a tree, in the lower left corner of the plate.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Vines or several branches spring from the first letter of the text and arch to the right.

component.illusobjdesc: Vines or several branches spring from the first letter of the text and arch to the right.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A scroll-like vine curls right of the last line of text and above the figure.

component.illusobjdesc: A scroll-like vine curls right of the last line of text and above the figure.

desc.objtitle: , Object 11 (Bentley b4, Erdman b4, Keynes b4)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A figure, apparently male, lies rigidly on his back. There are no clear indications of clothing. His face is turned upwards and his arms are at his side. His head rests on a cushion, pillow, or perhaps even a block of stone. He may be sleeping or dead. Above and to the right of his head is a small figure hovering in the air and facing to the left. His/her legs are spread apart and at least one arm is extended horizontally to the left.

component.illusobjdesc: A figure, apparently male, lies rigidly supine. There are no clear indications of clothing. His face is turned upwards and his arms are at his side. Perhaps he is sleeping or dead.
A very small figure hovers above the supine figure's head. He/she faces left, legs spread apart and with at least one arm raised horizontally and extended to the left.
The supine figure's head rests on a cushion, pillow, or perhaps even a block of stone.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A vine with one loop and perhaps some long leaves fills the space left of the heading number ("II"). Right of the number is a vine or branch with leaves and perhaps a few berries.

component.illusobjdesc: A vine with one loop and perhaps some long leaves fills the space left of the heading number ("II").
A vine or branch with leaves and perhaps a few berries fills the space right of the heading number ("II").

desc.objtitle: , Object 12 (Bentley b12, Erdman b12, Keynes b12)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A figure, probably male, lies supine on a bed, bier, or—if he is of great size—on hills. His legs appear to be crossed at the knees. His face is turned to his right and thus towards us; his right arm dangles rather limply at his side. There are no clear indications of clothing. Perhaps he is sleeping or dead. Lines of radiance appear around his head. This last motif suggests that this may be Christ, the "God" who "becomes as we are" (E3) in the text.

component.illusobjdesc: A figure, probably male, lies supine on a bed, bier, or—if he is of great size—on hills. His legs appear to be crossed at the knees. His face is turned to his right and thus towards us; his right arm dangles rather limply at his side. There are no clear indications of clothing. Perhaps he is sleeping or dead. Lines of radiance appear around his head. This last motif suggests that this may be Christ, the "God" who "becomes as we are" (E3) in the text.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Several vines decorate the spaces on all sides of the first line of text ("Therefore"). A single vine appears above the first four letters. Left of the word is a vine with three branches. A vine with a single loop and perhaps some leaves grows at the end of the word. Two vines lie beneath the word; the one on the right has a single loop and terminates in three leaves or small flowers.

component.illusobjdesc: A vine descends into the margin left of the word "Therefore." Another vine appears above the first four letters of "Therefore."
A vine with a single loop and perhaps long, slender leaves at its termination appears in the margin right of "Therefore."
A vine, perhaps with a few small leaves, appears under the first four letters of "Therefore."
A vine with a single loop appears beneath and to the right of the last four letters of "Therefore." It terminates in three leaves or small flowers.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A vine descends in the margin right of the third and fourth lines of text.

component.illusobjdesc: A vine descends in the margin right of the third and fourth lines of text.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A vine appears left of the last line of text ("is").

component.illusobjdesc: A vine appears left of the last line of text ("is").

illustration.illusobjdesc: A vine with two loops descends right of the last line of text ("is") and into the space between the text and the illustration at the bottom of the plate. The vine bears several leaves or small flowers.

component.illusobjdesc: A vine with two loops descends right of the last line of text ("is") and into the space between the text and the illustration at the bottom of the plate. The vine bears several leaves or small flowers.
